title-group.article-title: A modified imperialist competitive algorithm for constrained optimization of plate-fin heat exchangers

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Thermo-Fluids, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Malaysia

abstract.p: In this study, to handle the design optimization of plate-fin heat exchangers, a constrained version of a newly introduced evolutionary algorithm, the imperialist competitive algorithm, is proposed. Imperialist competitive algorithm was initially established for unconstrained optimization problems and different strategies such as penalty functions were employed to handle the constraints in the previous studies. In the proposed constrained imperialist competitive algorithm, a feasibility-based ranking is employed in the imperialist competitive algorithm method. Seven design parameters and various constraints are considered for the design optimization in which minimum weight and minimum total annual cost were considered as the autonomous objective functions. The results are compared with those obtained by a genetic algorithm approach combined with a static penalty function scheme. Also, a comparison between the proposed algorithm and the original imperialist competitive algorithm is performed. The simulation results show that both the proposed algorithm and imperialist competitive algorithm are of higher accuracy than the genetic algorithm, which is commonly used. Also, the numerical experiment indicates that the modification in the imperialist competitive algorithm leads to better performance of the algorithm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Heat exchangers (HEs) are extensively used in various aspects of industry and therefore are key parameters in plant design and operation. Among various types of HEs, plate-fin heat exchangers (PFHE), which are mostly known for their excellent heat transfer capacity and small size, are in use broadly in cryogenics, aerospace, automobile and military applications.

A PFHE is extremely flexible since it could work under any arrangement of liquid, gas and two-phase fluids. Among various types of fins, including wavy, offset-strip, louver, perforated and pin fins, that have been employed in HEs for boosting heat transfer rate, rectangular offset-strip fins are employed in this study.

These fins are characterized by their compactness, reliability and high heat transfer efficiency.1 Figure 1 depicts a drawing of a typical PFHE and an offset-strip fin. Figure 1.
(a) Core structure of a PFHE, (b) detailed view of an offset-strip fin.

The design process of any HE, including PFHEs, is a complicated job since the selected geometrical and parameters for a specified heat duty and operational conditions, should satisfy any particular requirements, such as size limitations, and also leads to a desired optimum state. This complexity has motivated various researchers to present practical methods. In the early studies, traditional mathematical methods and formulation were presented.2–5 Artificial intelligence6 and simulated annealing7 were also employed in this domain. With the emergence of genetic algorithms (GAs) in the early 1990s, the evolutionary computation method proved its efficiency in large-scale combinatorial problems. GAs were successfully applied for design optimization of shell-and-tube heat exchangers in the early attempts.8,9 GAs have been also employed in PFHE design in various studies10–13 considering different objective function such as minimum weight, minimum total annual cost, minimum number of entropy generation units and minimum total amount of pressure drops. In recent years, many evolutionary algorithms (EAs) have been proposed based on diverse evolutionary mechanisms such as swarm intelligence in particle swarm optimization (PSO)14 and musical improvisation in harmony search algorithm.15 Due to the better performance of these algorithms on benchmark problems compared to GAs, they were also employed in compact heat exchanger design and optimization to take advantage of their great abilities in finding near-optimum solutions.16–21 Recently, inspired by the way countries improve in an imperialist system, imperialist competitive algorithm (ICA) was introduced.22 ICA, which makes use of cultural interactions of human life instead of the usual genetic or physical evolution, has been showing great success in various engineering applications23–26 as well as benchmark problems.22 In all previous studies on compact heat exchangers, static penalty function methods, which are easy to implement, have been employed for constraint handing since the GAs or other EAs cannot handle the constraints directly. The penalty functions relate the level of constraint violation to a corresponding fitness value and add it to the original fitness function; therefore the constrained problem is converted to an unconstrained one. By doing so, the solutions that violate the constraints will be eliminated throughout the evolution process since they will have higher fitness values. The main difficulty of penalty functions is that their efficiencies depend greatly on the fine-tuning of their parameters. Coello Coello27 presents a comprehensive review of the various constraint handling methods employed in EAs. The parameter is set in a trial-and-error process, which is time-consuming and error-prone. To avoid this, in this study a novel version of ICA is presented in the optimization task of the PFHE. The new algorithm named constrained ICA or CICA, does not need any parameter setting for constraint handling and hence is very useful in heat exchanger design and other engineering applications where usually a large number of constraints should be satisfied during the course of optimization.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. In ‘Thermal modeling’ section, a brief overview of the PFHE thermal modeling is presented. ‘The optimization algorithm’ section sheds light on the main ideas and operators of ICA, the conventional penalty function methods and the proposed constrained ICA. ‘Objectives and cost evaluation’ section presents the objectives and the method of cost evaluation while the ‘Case study’ section presents the case study selected from the previous studies. The numerical results on two example studies are presented in the ‘Numerical results’ section and finally, the conclusions are drawn in the last section.

sec.title: Thermal modeling
sec.p: For thermal modeling of the PFHE, it is assumed that both cold- and hot-side fluids behave as ideal gases. The thermodynamic properties of air are those of an average temperature and considered to be constant. The working condition is assumed to be steady state. Thermal resistance of walls and fouling factors are not considered in the thermal modeling; and finally number of cold-side layers is one more than those of hot-side layers to reduce the thermal waste to the ambient air.

sec.title: Imperialist competitive algorithm
sec.p: ICA was initially formulated for unconstrained optimization problems; hence, for constrained problems, a constrained handling method should be employed in the algorithm. Penalty function methods are the most popular constraint handling scheme that have been extensively employed in engineering problems. However, the performance of these methods greatly depends on the fine-tuning of their parameters. These problem-dependant parameters are selected by a trial-and-error process that could be time-consuming and error-prone. To eliminate this process, in the proposed method, constraints are handled within the main algorithm and no additional parameters would be emerged. The original algorithm, for an unconstrained problem, could generally be described in six steps, which are as follows.

sec.title: Step 1: Initial empires creation
sec.p: Like other evolutionary algorithms, ICA begins with randomly generating a set of possible solutions, each of them called a country. The number of the initial countries depends on the problem and is set by the user. In an N-dimensional optimization problem a country is a 1 * N array defined as follows (16)country=[P1,P2,P3,…,PN]

The merit of all countries is calculated using the fitness function and a corresponding power is assigned to each of them. Considering a minimization problem, countries with the lowest fitness function are the most powerful ones. Having determined the power of all countries, a particular number of the most powerful ones, Nimp, are considered as imperialist countries and others, called colonial countries, are divided among them. In this process, the number of colonial countries of each imperialist depends solely on its power. The process of empire creation is shown schematically in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Creating the initial empires. The more powerful an imperialist is, the more colonies it possesses.

sec.title: Step 2: Assimilation policy
sec.p:
After creating the initial empires, the assimilation process begins. Each imperialist forces its colonies to move toward it in an attempt to improve them. This process is shown schematically in Figure 3 where culture and language could relate to any dimension of the problem. Figure 3.
The assimilation policy. The colonies move toward their imperialist country.

Each colony moves with the amount of x units toward its imperialist, where x is a random number with uniform distribution that is described as follows (17)x ~U(0,β*d) In equation (17), d is the distance of a colony from its corresponding imperialist, and β is a number greater than that tunes the movement rate. The assimilation policy is comparable with the movement of particles toward the global and local best solutions in the particle swarm optimization (PSO).14

sec.title: Step 3: Revolution
sec.p: Inspired by the mutation process in GAs, a certain number of countries is facing a sudden change that is called revelation. The revolution helps the algorithm to escape the possible local optima traps. Any conventional mutation mechanism could be employed in this stage.

sec.title: Step 4: Updating the state of the empire
sec.p: Any time during the assimilation policy, if any colony reaches a better stage compared to its imperialist and acquires a more powerful position, it would be considered as the imperialist onwards.

sec.title: Step 5: Imperialistic competition
sec.p: In each iteration, a competition takes place among all imperialists for drawing more colonies to their empires. The weakest country of the weakest empire is selected, and randomly assigned to one of the other empires based on their relative powers. The takeover probability of each imperialist is proportionate to its power. The weak empires would eventually lose all their colonies and collapse.

sec.title: Step 6: Convergence
sec.p: Ideally, the algorithm continues until only one empire exists in the entire solution domain. However, different termination criteria such as achieving a certain level of accuracy or a certain number of iterations can be set as well.

sec.title: Penalty function
sec.p: A general constrained minimization problem can be described as follows (18)Minimisef(x),x=[x1,…,xk] where equality and inequality constraints are as follows (19)gj(X)≤0,j=1,…,m and (20)xi,min≤xi≤xi,max, i=1,…,k Penalty function methods are the most popular constraint handling schemes and have been widely employed in evolutionary-based optimization of thermal systems including PFHEs The penalty functions relate the level of constraint violation to a corresponding fitness value and add it to the original fitness function; therefore the constrained problem is converted to an unconstrained one. The new unconstrained problem is formulated as follows (21)Minimisef(x)+∑j=1mφ(gj(x)) Subject to equation (20).

φ is a function defined by the user. For the static penalty function, this function is described as follows. Static penalty function is the easiest and has been the most popular constraint-handling method in evolutionary algorithms (22)φ(gj(x))=R·νj(x)2

The penalty parameter, R, has an important role in the success of a penalty function. The value of R is usually larger than the fitness value, f(x). However, it cannot be too excessive since it alters the constraint handling scheme to a rejection strategy where any infeasible solution will be immediately eliminated from the search space. A reject strategy degrades the search efficiency of the algorithm. In contrast when light penalties are considered, the final solutions may be infeasible and therefore inaccurate. There is no exact procedure for determining the value of R, though some suggestions are available in the literature, therefore it has to be set through experiment and numerous trials.

sec.title: The proposed constrained ICA
sec.p:
Inspired by feasibility-based grouping method proposed by Yuchi and Kim,30 a modified version of ICA is proposed for handling constrained optimization problems. In this method, all the initial countries are evaluated based upon both the constraints and fitness function. At first, all countries are divided into two groups, i.e. feasible solutions and infeasible ones. The feasible countries are then assigned a corresponding power based on their fitness function values. The imperialist countries are selected from the best feasible countries and all the remaining ones are divided among them as the colonies. The following rules are considered for creating the initial empires.
Rule 1 – Only feasible countries could be assigned as the imperialist.
Rule 2 – If the number of initial feasible solutions (NFS) is less than the number of imperialist countries (Nimp), the number of imperialists is, for the time being, reduced to NFS.

After creating the initial empires, the assimilation policy begins similar to the original ICA. In the proposed CICA, after a certain number of iterations referred to as Nrg, all countries are considered together and grouped to feasible and infeasible solutions again. The new empires are created based on the mentioned rules and optimization continues. The regrouping process helps the algorithm to escape from the possible local optima traps. Compared to the original ICA where a weak country transfers the information within the solution domain, the regrouping idea is more efficient in helping all countries communicate and share their valuable information. The optimum value of Nrg is found to be 10. The other advantages of the proposed algorithm over the original ICA is that no empire collapses during the evolution process that leads to a higher intensity of local search around different solutions. The revolution process takes place right before regrouping. To account for elitism, only infeasible solutions would randomly face revolution process and feasible ones remain intact. In case of having no infeasible solutions, the revolution takes place within any of the colonial countries where imperialists would remain undamaged. The flowchart of the proposed CICA is presented in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Flow chart of the proposed CICA.

sec.title: Objectives and cost evaluation
sec.p: Weight minimization and minimization of total annual cost are set as two objectives for optimum design of PFHE. The former is mainly associated with the capital cost of the PFHE while the latter account for both capital and operational costs.

Following the method used in Xie et al.,11 Yousefi and Darus18 and Sanaye and Hajabdollahi,31 the annual cost is set to be the sum of annual investment cost and the operating costs. Only electricity price is considered as the operating cost and other possible expenses such as maintenance costs are not taken into account (23)Cinv=Af·CA·Atotn (24)Cop=[kelτΔP·mη·ρ]a+[kelτΔP·mη·ρ]b (25)TAC=Cin+Cop CA and n are cost per unit surface area and the exponent of non-linear increase with the area increase, respectively. kel, τ and η are the electricity price, hours of operation and compressor efficiency, respectively. Af is the annual coefficient factor that is defined as follows (26)Af=r1-(1+r)-y Interest rate and depreciation time are represented by r and y, respectively. sec.title: Case study
sec.p:
A cross-flow PFHE should be designed for a heat duty of 160 kW. The pressure drop limits for cold- and hot-air sides are set to 2 kPa and 4 kPa, respectively. The gas and air inlet temperatures are 513 K and 277 K, respectively. The gas flows through the PFHE with a mass flow rate of 0.8962 kg/s while mass flow rate of air is 0.8296 kg/s. The inlet pressure of both fluids is 100 kPa. The size limitation of the PFHE is 1 m for each flow side and 0.5 m for no-flow length. The heat exchanger material is aluminum with density of 2700 kg/m3. The lower and upper limits of the seven design variables are presented in Table 2. Two optimization objectives, i.e. minimum weight and minimum total annual cost are considered as the design basis. Table 2.

sec.title: Weight minimization (example A)
sec.p: The proposed algorithm is employed to generate the optimum configuration of the PFHE for achieving the desired objective. For both examples, the results are compared with those achieved by a conventional GA that uses a static penalty function for constraint handling. To select the proper values of crossover probability and mutation rate for GA, a series of experiments are carried out. The values of 0.5 and 0.005 for crossover probability and mutation rate are found to lead to the best performance of GA. The same values were used in Peng and Ling.12 The population size and termination criterion are chosen similar to the CICA algorithm. Each algorithm was performed 10 times on each example and the presented result was the best outcome.

Taking into consideration the pressure drop, size and heat duty limitations, the task is to find the optimum configuration of the PFHE for the minimum weight design. The proposed CICA is employed for the optimization task. A real-value representation of the decision variables is employed. Each solution, country, consists of nine cells where the first seven represent each of the decision variables and the last two are related to the fitness value and constraint violations, in turn. For the constraint-indicator cell, the value 0 indicates a feasible solution while the value 1 corresponds to an infeasible one. Based on the proposed algorithm, only countries with a constraint-indicator of 0 could be assigned as imperialist countries. The required parameters of the CICA algorithm are set based on the recommendations of Atashpaz-Gargari and Lucas.22 The revolution rate and β value are set to 0.01 and 2, respectively. The value of Nimp is set to 1/10 of the population size, i.e. number of all countries.

In the beginning, an experiment is carried out to determine the appropriate number of countries. The reported results throughout the study are the best solution out of 10 executions of the computer program since the results could be different due to the stochastic nature of the evolutionary algorithms. For weight minimization, the variation of the final result of the objective function with number of countries selected for the optimization task is presented in Figure 5. When increasing the number of countries to more than 50, the changes in the result is considerable; however, after reaching a population of 100, these changes become minute. The changes in the objective function value stops after 150. Hence, to avoid unnecessary extra computational time, the number of countries, the size of the population, is set to 150 throughout this study. Figure 5.
The effect of variation of the number of countries on the minimum weight objective.

The evolution process of the weight minimization by the proposed CICA is presented in Figure 6. Similar to the other evolutionary algorithms, the decrease in the early stages of the optimization process is significant (first 10 decades). However, on the contrary to the GA and the original ICA12,22,23 the proposed algorithm continues to progress extensively even after 100 decades. The decrease in the objective function becomes negligible after 400 decades. The termination criterion is set to 500 decades and the optimization is terminated in this stage. The optimum configuration of PFHE, obtained by the algorithm, gives a minimum weight of 23.85 kg. Table 3 shows the optimum designed obtained by the proposed method and GA. The proposed method has improved the objective function by 29.1%. As it is expected, the pressure drops of both sides are close to their maximum allowed bounds for a minimum total annual cost design. sec.title: Cost minimization (example B)
sec.p:
In this part, the optimization target is to find the optimum configuration of the PFHE for minimum total annual cost. Figure 7 illustrates the evolution process of the optimization process for this objective. A similar trend to the previous objective is observed. On the contrary to the weight minimization process, the variation of objective function becomes minute after 100 decades. However, the algorithm is allowed to continue for 500 decades. Finally, the minimum total annual cost (TAC) is found to be 586.0$. In Table 4, the optimum configuration and the corresponding pressure drops, no-flow length and weight are presented for both GA and CICA methods. sec.title: A comparison between ICA and the proposed CICA
sec.p:
In this subsection a brief investigation is carried out to compare the efficiency of the proposed CICA and the original ICA algorithms. A static penalty function method is employed for constraint handling. The penalty parameters are selected similar to those employed in GA approach. The parameters of ICA are set similar to those that were used in the previous section for the CICA. The termination criterion is set to reaching 500 iterations. For both example studies the objective function and the convergence rate, i.e. number of iterations that is needed for convergence, is presented. Table 5 presents the results for both objectives. Due to the stochastic nature of the evolutionary computation, the convergence rate and the optimum solution may vary for different executions of the computer code. Therefore, for the objective function, the best, the worst and the mean values of 10 executions are presented. The convergence rate is the average of all the obtained values. It can be seen that in both examples CICA provides better results. However, ICA converges to optimum configuration faster when compared to the CICA. It is mainly because it is related to the more intense global search process of the CICA, which is the result of the regular regrouping of the empires.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Design optimization of PFHEs was carried out in this study by a novel EA. The novel EA, which uses feasibility-based grouping procedure, was proposed based on the newly introduced ICA. The proposed algorithm facilitates the ICA by a constraint-handling capability that does not require any parameter setting. A large number of design variables and constraints were considered for a minimum cost and a minimum weight design. A well-studied problem from the previous studies was considered for testing the performance of the proposed algorithm. The main contributions’ findings and contributions of this work are as follows.
A novel evolutionary algorithm was proposed and successfully tested for constrained optimization problems.
Compared to the GA and ICA, the proposed algorithm was shown to be better in optimization design of PFHEs.

The proposed algorithm and the design procedure can be applied, without much additional effort, for any constrained optimization problem including design process of other thermal devices such as fin-and-tube heat exchangers, sell-and-tube heat exchangers and recuperators.
